dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is crammed with GUESTS OF ALL AGES. Birthday decorations announce the occasion. We move through the party behind AGNES, the lady of the house, the woman behind the hands from the opening montag She's carrying a tray, offering appetizers. The occasional GUEST kisses Agnes on the cheek or says "t you" but mostly people just take a piece off the tray wit paying much attention to her. She doesn’t mind it at all. She’s happy unseen. LAUGHTER AND CHATTER ALL AROUND. Agnes glides by LOUIE, her husband, who’s sitting on the couch with a FEW FRIENDS, shooting the breeze. Louie palm few appetizers and passes them around to his pals.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Thanks, babe. You’re the best. RONNIE, Louie’s close friend, takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Amazing, Agnes. Really. Always. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes nods and moves down the hallway into the den where TEENAGE BOYS are sitting around with her son GABE (17), watching a YouTube video and laughing their heads off.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hey Mom, more salami. Agnes smiles and nods, turns on her heels, heading back t the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crucifix hangs in the window above Agnes who is n expertly chopping up more salami and arranging the slices a large plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is moving through the crowded living room with the plate of salami when Louie and his Friends burst out laughing. She jumps just as Louie's plate slides off his and shatters into a dozen pieces on the floor. Ronnie and others all hoot. They’ve been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Careful. I'll be right there. Don’t move. Agnes hurries to the hallway into the den to give Gabe th salami plate.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes enters with a broom and a dust pan. She kneels next Louie and sweeps up the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. Seriously. He gives her a kiss. AGNES (CONT’D) Are you having fun?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Great time.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m glad. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: We're going to go up front and smoke.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Just one. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’1l call you for cake.

dialogues.speaker: . LOUIE
dialogues.text: Is Ziggy around?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: He’s around. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Tell him to come join us. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT Agnes washes the broken pieces of Louie’s plate. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes gets glue out of the kitchen drawer. Spreads all th pieces of Louie’s broken plate out on the counter and attempts to fit them together. ESZTER, Agnes’ sister-in-law, comes in. She gives Agnes a baffled look.

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER
dialogues.text: Do you need a hand?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What? Oh. No. I’m-- (re: plate) I’m missing a piece. It’s tiny. I’ll never find it.

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER
dialogues.text: There’s no shame in asking for help, you know. You don’t have to do everything.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I know. I know. But-- I like doing everything. I don’t need any help. Thank you.  10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie and his friends walk back into the house to find Ag crawling around on her knees looking for the tiny missing piece.

dialogues.speaker: _ LOUIE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: There's a piece missing. From the plate. I don’t want anyone to step on--

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Agnes. Stand up! She ignores him and continues to look. He puts a hand on shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Later, okay? Not tonight. Please. It’s not like anyone ever walks around here barefoot. She stands, disappointed, mission aborted.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're so cute. Their oldest son, ZIGGY (19), scrutinizes them from acros the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes pulls the frosted cake out of the refrigerator. She sticks candles in the cake and looks at it for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding the cake with the lit candles, Agnes walks out of kitchen into the dining room. ALL THE PARTY GUESTS gather

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: (singing loudly) Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you, happy birthday-- dear... Agnes, happy birthday to you. Agnes sets the cake down on the dining room table and loo at it, pleased, her face glowing in the candlelight. This indeed HER birthday party. This is her world. Her life. S blows out the candles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Speech! Speech! EVERYONE LAUGHS. They know Agnes well enough to get the j Agnes swallows hard. Clearly, she’s uncomfortable with ev hint of attention.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (whispering) Thank you, everyone. Ziggy inches closer.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Speak up, ma!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Oh, leave the woman alone, will you? Agnes clears her throat, about to speak. Everyone quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Who wants cake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humming to herself, Agnes puts the last of the party dish away. The house is hers again; the guests gone, her men asleep upstairs. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits down at the kitchen table, exhausted. She pour herself a large glass of red wine. Suddenly, she remember something that sends her out of the room excitedly. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is halfway through unwrapping her presents. They’ r 1 pretty generic: a vase, a wooden ladle, a book

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (reading book title) Aging with Grace: What the Nun Study Teaches Us About Leading Longer, Healthier, and More Meaningful Lives. She rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Zig. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She puts the book away. Opens and reads a series of Hallm cards. Opens a small box and finds an iPhone inside. Stares at i if it came from the future. Puts it down with little interest. Then she unwraps a long, rectangular present. It's a Ravensburger puzzle, 1500 pieces. A beautiful contemporar map of the world. Agnes studies the puzzle, then sets it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes crawls into bed next to Louie who is SNORING LOUDLY She lies there awake for a while. An old ALARM CLOCK TICKS on the night table on Louie’s si of the bed. Agnes listens to the TICKING. Louie groans and turns onto his side, putting his arm around her. The SNORING stops. Agnes closes her eyes, relieved. A few seconds later, the SNORING starts up again. But she already asleep.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNORING KEEPS GOING. THE CLOCK TICKS.
dialogues.text: Card: PUZZLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burning street lights turn off neighborhood by neighborho as night succumbs. WE HEAR THE CLOCK TICKING. FOLLOWED BY AGNES’S WHISPERS,

dialogues.speaker: PRAYERS RECITED AND REPEATED
dialogues.text: ACCOMPANIED BY LOUIE’S SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day breaks over the working-class neighborhood. Modest ho line the residential streets, most darkened, but some alr busy with early morning rituals. AGNES'S WHISPERS CONTINUE. THE TICKING CLOCK KEEPS TIME. LOUIE’S SNORING KEEPS GOING. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We move closer to a little side street to find Agnes and Louie’s simple house with its well-kept front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bars of sunlight streak the window glass, filtering into dimness of the room. Agnes is wide awake with her eyes closed, WHISPERING. Behind her, Louie is asleep on his back, mouth open, SNOR As we glide closer to her we can make out Agnes's words, from prayers:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (whispering to herself) Eleven, ten, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one. She opens her eyes, expecting... something. Nothing happe She listens to the CLOCK TICKING. Quickly closes her eyes again. It’s a game of sorts. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Seven, six, five, four, three, two, one. Agnes opens her eyes. Nothing. She’s clearly disappointed Louie lets out a NASALLY SNORE. She giggles. She closes h eyes again in anticipation. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Five, four, three, two, one. Now. THE ALARM BELL RINGS. She opens her eyes and smiles to herself in victory. Sits up in bed. Leans over Louie and turns the ALARM BELL OFF. Louie continues to sleep. Agnes shakes him. AGNES (CONT’D) Lou. Honey. Louie.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (groggy) What?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Time to get up.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s a new day. He turns over on his side, his back to her. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Five more minutes. (to Louie) Honey, time to get up.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Five more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering to herself) Please. Please. 18 INT. GABE’S BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights on! In the TV monitor hooked up to an XBox, we see Agnes's reflection as she shuffles in to wake up her youn son Gabe. She touches his shoulder tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Five more minutes, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks down the corridor, HUMMING TO HERSELF, and KN on a bedroom door. No response. She KNOCKS AGAIN. 20 INT. ZIGGY’S BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNIN Lights on! Ziggy, bare-chested and sporting a botched tat buries himself under the covers. In the large mirror, we Agnes move in.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Ten more minutes, Mom. I swear. Agnes smiles to herself as she watches Ziggy go back to sleep. She starts picking up dirty clothes off the floor desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks down the stairs when LOUD HIP HOP EXPLODES FR GABE’S ROOM. Agnes stops on the stairs, turns and looks up to calmly watch: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Louie storming out of the bathroom, shaving cream hanging from his chin, razor in hand. He KNOCKS on Gabe’s door.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Turn that off, goddamnit! Every morning the same crap. The HIP HOP MUSIC IS LOWERED. Louie then catches Agnes's watchful eye. He shrugs innocently at her. She smiles at

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Manchego omelette? He beams at the suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Be down in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes inspects her hands by holding them up to the sunlig blasting the glass. THE SOUND OF ZIGGY LAUGHING REVERBERATES FROM UPSTAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop. Gabe. Stop. I’m serious. I’m gonna pee my pants. Agnes GRINDS COFFEE BEANS IN THE GRINDER. She walks over to get a coffee mug when her gaze falls on framed photo of an OLDER MAN standing with YOUNG AGNES in very same kitchen. Tears start streaming down her face. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is making omelettes and sausages while Louie and Zi chat over coffee; both men are wearing clean mechanics coveralls. Gabe is hunched over Agnes’s new iPhone.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE GABE
dialogues.text: (to Ziggy) Hey, Mom, what kind of apps Which grit do you use_when do you want? you're doing the final sanding?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Louie) I don’t want apps. I don’t Are you really quizzing me want that phone. Mine’s over breakfast? perfectly fine. You take it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ziggy) | I'm not quizzing you. I saw you using a 1200 grit the other day and that's never gonna work.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about this at home, dad. I need a break. 10. 23

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (to Agnes) How about the weather channel?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have a radio and a window. I know when it’s going to rain.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE GABE
dialogues.text: You'll get a break once you (to Agnes do everything right, Zig. I put my number and Ziggy 's and Dad's on speed dial. Who else do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Mom, do you need any help cooking? Agnes shakes her head, then puts eggs and sausages on a p and hands it to Gabe. ZIGGY (CONT’D) GABE (to Louie) (to Agnes) Fine. What? I should've used What about Ezster? And the 400? Church ladies?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE AGNES
dialogues.text: That or 600. (to Gabe) I don't _know why I wouldn't just call them from the home phone. Gabe throws up his hands, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Will someone please explain to my mother why she has to stop living in the 20th century?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Are you even gonna use it, Mom?.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I guess I might use it like my old phone. For emergencies.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Forget it!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t like all this technology. Is that really so crazy? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yes. Absolutely. A hundred percent.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Leave your mother alone. She doesn't like gadgets.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Then why did we get it for her?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Because it’s a thoughtful gift.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Not if she never uses it. (to Agnes) Just try it. Google something. Recipes. Bible study. Whatever. Everything in the world is inside this one device.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. It's like carrying a little robot in your purse. A little alien robot friend. I don’t need it.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Clearly it doesn’t need you either. Louie slaps Gabe’s shoulder. Agnes serves Louie and Ziggy Gabe takes a series of pictures of Agnes with her iPhone:

dialogues.speaker: . AGNES KITCHEN PORTRAITS 24
dialogues.text: We move through the series of iPhone photos of Agnes, goi through a range of expressions flickering across her face affection, sadness, exhaustion, weariness, quiet judgment and, finally Agnes’s hand blocking the phone.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Enough. You're all gonna be late. INT. FRONT PORCH. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 25 Agnes sits alone on the front porch, delighting in a piec her birthday cake, watching the daylight moon in the sky. Every bite is a calm celebration. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks back into the house and spots the puzzle box, still sitting in its plastic wrapping on the table with t other gifts. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She moves closer to the table. Shuts her eyes and randoml places her finger on the puzzle map picture on the box to She opens her eyes, looks at what she’s pointed to:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Belgium! She makes a face and walks into the kitchen. We stay in t dining room. Hear the SINK WATER TURN ON. FOLLOWED BY THE RADIO, THE DIAL MOVING, LANDING ON CLASSICAL MUSIC. Suddenly, she marches back in, determined. Picks the puzz box up and quickly, as if forcing herself against her bet judgement, rips off the plastic wrapping and opens the bo She takes out the sheet of paper with instructions on it puts her hand in the loose pile of puzzle pieces, letting them sift through her fingers. It's like she's running he hand through sand or water; there's something sensual abo it. A second later, she dumps the puzzle pieces onto the tabl and sits down. Starts turning pieces over quickly. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 27 POLKA MUSIC ON THE RADIO, a different program. Agnes hasn moved from her seat in hours. She’s fitting the last few pieces of the puzzle into place, rubbing her tired eyes. Suddenly she notices the time and leaps from her seat. INT. KITCHEN SIDE ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes quickly puts in a load of laundry.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON 29
dialogues.text: Agnes drives through the streets of West Bridgeport. She’ a hurry but she steers carefully, slow and measured, with little confidence, foot jumping back and forth from gas p to brake, far from oblivious to the tension of the HONKS behind her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m trying. I know. I’m trying.

dialogues.speaker: AGAINST CANNED SOUNDS OF MUZAK
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: --Agnes moves quickly up and down the brightly lit aisles the supermarket. --She chooses one cereal, then quickly looks at its ingredients, then puts it back on the shelf, then picks another and throws it in her cart, then reconsiders, puts back and picks the original cereal... --She stands at the deli counter watching impatiently whi PIMPLY ADOLESCENT BOY endlessly slices ham for her... --She peers through the frosted windows of the frozen foo aisle... --She hurries down the fruit aisle, pushing her cart like race car driver. -She stuffs cucumbers into a plastic bag in the produce section... -She bags her groceries one by one just as soon as a particularly slow GROCERY CLERK scans them at the registe one after another. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. BE It’s excruciating for her to wait, but she keeps the same polite, patient, slightly quizzical expression on her fac The Grocery Clerk finishes. Agnes swipes her charge card. Punches in the number. The sound of a receipt printing.

dialogues.speaker: GROCERY CLERK
dialogues.text: All set.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Thank you. She grabs her bag and rushes off. Comes back and gets her receipt.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON 31
dialogues.text: Agnes drives back home through the streets of West Bridgeport. There’s more traffic than earlier. It’s rush hour. She checks the dashboard clock. HONKS THE HORN when light turns green.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 32
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN SIDE ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING Agnes moves the wet laundry to the dryer.  34 35 14. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 34 Agnes runs over to the sink, fills a pot with boiling wat and grabs a jar of tomato sauce from the cupboard. She he the FRONT DOOR OPEN AND SHUT. A beat later, Gabe walks in

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hey. He gives her a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Hi, sweety. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Kind of whatever. Chess club was cool. Hockey was canceled; Coach Wilson got bad diarrhea. (laughing) How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Busy. Pretty busy.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Any emergencies?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: None. Thank God. He laughs and grabs an apple off the table. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 35 Wearing dirty coveralls, Ziggy walks in to set up the tab He checks out the finished puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom, what do I do with this thing on--? Agnes runs in, wiping her hands in a kitchen towel.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Sorry. She breaks the puzzle up.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: No, don’t! Too late. She throws puzzle pieces into the box.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s 1500 pieces, Mom. She shrugs. Louie comes down the stairs post-shower. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Mom just--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Dinner is almost ready.

dialogues.speaker: _ LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to Ziggy) You're not going to change?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Mom asked me to set the table.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: In these filthy clothes?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I’1l do it.
35 36 Agnes is lying in bed, struggling to make out the small p of the puzzle instructions with an old magnifying glass. Louie is changing into his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: He's lazy. He looks at her, she’s trying to read. LOUIE (CONT’D) Agnes, are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Shhh. Lower your voice.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What are you reading there?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Puzzle instructions.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You put the pieces together until you run out, what other instructions do you need? ___ AGNES ; Suggestions. Strategies. It doesn’t matter. She puts the paper away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You're so cute. (pause) Puzzles are for children, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't think he's lazy.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: He just sits there until I ask him to do something. He'll do whatever I tell him but he won't take any initiative. All day long. 16. 36 Louie faces her in his pajama bottoms, shirtless. Agnes e him, her expression betraying worry.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Huh? LOUIE ; You were looking at me with some kind of-- some kind of look in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I know you, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: There was no look--

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Just say it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: There was no look.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I turned down a doughnut today. Okay? A jelly doughnut! Do you know how hard that was for me?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You should be very proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I am. I’m smoking a lot less. For you. For us. Cholesterol is a genetic thing. It’s not my fault... He turns the lights off and gets in bed, putting his arm around her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to lose you. 1 hi LOUIE au in thet, pray a) me! (pause) Is iP hot in here? She sighs, gets up and opens a crack in the window. Stops staring out at: Ziggy, smoking a cigarette outside, looking through messa on his phone, a picture of youthful loneliness. She gets in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes steers her car into the church parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: THE ORGAN IS BEING TUNED, WAY TOO LOUD AND SCREECHY.
dialogues.text: Brightly colored light streams through the giant stained glass windows. Agnes walks through the entrance, waves to THE SHORT WOMA mopping the floors and crosses to a side door where a han written sign reads: ST. STEPHENS LADIES GUILD MEETING. She opens the door and walks down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children's Sunday School drawings decorate every inch of every wall. The meeting is in progress: HOUSEWIVES (30s-70s) sit ina circle of chairs, Agnes and Ezster amongst them. FANNY, 5 overly made-up, is the Ladies Guild leader.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Well, Lent starts in five days. Since we're no longer doing the soup kitchen, we need to start organizing a food drive. The women start passing around a sign-up sheet. Agnes's attention is on the children’s drawings: the broken lines the bright colors, the naive settings - she’s mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is it true Father Kutash is only going to do confession once a month now? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No one shows up. There's nothing we can do about it. The sign-up sheet gets to Agnes and she takes the pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to herself, loudly) I guess we'll just pack our sins into neat monthly portions. Everyone stares at her. She turns beet red. Quickly signs name. AGNES (CONT’D) (passing the sheet) I’m sorry. It was a joke. I didn’t realize I was speaking out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church Ladies exit the building and head to their cars. Agnes is sitting in her parked car, laughing to herself a CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS ON THE RADIO. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY Al Agnes dumps her bags down on the counter. Then she walks to the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Aunt Emily. It's Agnes. We missed you at the party. How are you? I heard. Completely broken? Which part? The fifth what? Fifth metatarsal? I don’t know what that is. I'm so sorry. Good, good. No. It’s just-- I have a question. The present you sent me with Vlad. The puzzle. Yeah. No, it’s very nice. Where did you buy it? Agnes grabs a pencil and a note pad while she listens, an scrawls something down.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. (disappointed) Oh, that’s too bad. No. I haven’t been to New York in years. I couldn’t ask Vlad. Online? Louie says we shouldn't give credit card numbers online. I guess sometimes it’s better to be paranoid. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: His friend Ronnie had his identity stolen. His life was hell for nine months. Anyway, thanks. All the best. Bye bye. She hangs up. Looks down at the note pad, where she has written: ‘Thompson and 3rd street.’ INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 42 Agnes stares at the assembled world map puzzle on the tab with a great deal of pride. She did it again! And in half time. She looks at the world. The world looks back at her. Then starts taking it apart. INT. DEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes has a stack of blank Hallmark invitations and envel on the table, along with stamps and extra pens. She uses red pen to inscribe something in one card. Then puts the away. Takes another, repeats. Adds it to the pile.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 44
dialogues.text: INT. GABE'S ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes searches through Gabe's closet. A small box of cond falls out from behind a pile of old clothes and onto the ground. Agnes stares at it, then puts it back. INT. BASEMENT. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 46 A dim light turns on to reveal taxidermied fish of every possible size, mounted on the wall and displayed on stand all around. There are also stacks of fishing poles and bo of fly-fishing supplies. Agnes goes into a corner of the basement and rummages thr boxes and toys, until:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Tada! She finds a very old children’s puzzle set: The Incredibl Hulk. Only a hundred pieces. She immediately sits down on basement floor, empties out the box and starts assembling pieces. She’s becoming an addict.  47 20. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family around the table, plus NICKI, 17, Gabe’s girlfriend. Agnes comes in from the kitchen with a gorgeous stuffed chicken dish she adds to a salad assembled in the likenes a fish. There’s homemade bread along with other elaborate dishes on the table.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: The chicken is stuffed with potatoes and-

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Mom! Nicki!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Nicki) I thought you just didn't eat red meat.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: I'm vegan. GABE . We went through this already, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: So you never ever eat chicken?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (to, Nicki) It's like she’s hoping you'll forget. It’s so embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I should have made fish. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t eat any animals, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But she has to have protein, she’s still growing.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Mom, don’t say dumb shit like that--

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Hey. Enough. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Nicki) The way we were raised, everything had to come with meat. I’m sorry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: It's fine. I can eat the salad. And bread. I’m fine. Nicki takes the salad, stirs it up with salad tongs and serves herself. Agnes watches confused.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Nicki) Have you always been this way?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Nicki’s also a Buddhist.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That sounds interesting.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You know, I have no idea what that really means. Buddhist. I always hear people talking about Buddhism and celebrities and nobody says what it is.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: It's like-- Like the root of all suffering is our desire not to suffer. Intrigued by this strange young woman, Agnes stares, forgetting the food.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So we have to give up on the idea of being happy Ziggy eats quietly. Gabe’s practically glowing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (impressed) You don't care about being happy?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: I try not to think that way. Happiness is an illusion. Agnes serves herself some chicken.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are your parents unhappy? Ziggy cracks up. Nicki stares, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I mean, like Buddhist? Did they raise you this way? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: God. No. They’re stuck in the past.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Isn't Buddhism also from the past?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: No. Yeah. I mean they’re more conventional Western thinkers. When they bother to think. That’s what I mean. Louie laughs, he likes Nicki’s spirit. Agnes gives hima look, she’s not amused. Ziggy clocks his mother’s anguish a GABE Nicki won't even-- She doesn't even kill mosquitoes.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I read something about this kid who drowned in a river because a Buddhist monk was the only one watching him and if you're a Buddhist you're not supposed to try to save people's lives. Like you're not supposed to interfere with their path.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: That doesn't sound true.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why can't Buddhists save lives?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Where did you read that?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: It was an article. It was a real article on like the Huffington Post or something.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, that's not Buddhism. Buddhism respects life. It just has a different approach to death and suffering.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That monk should be shot.

dialogues.speaker: GABE/AGNES
dialogues.text: Dad! /Louie!

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Are you volunteering, Dad? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: No. He’s right. I mean. Metaphorically. An awkward pause among the less righteous.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Metaphorically. I get it. He locks eyes with Agnes who stares daggers at him. It’s if he’s betrayed her somehow.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: How’s your chicken, Louie?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: It’s good. He notices Nicki looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A little dry. But good. Agnes stands up alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: There’s gravy. EXT. BACKYARD. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING B48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight. All is calm and quiet. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes makes coffee. Ziggy, looking groggy, comes in and, without saying a word, takes the eggs out of the fridge a starts breaking them into a bowl. He likes to help.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: What’s good about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes waits on the mostly empty train platform, shivering slightly. A FEW BUSINESS MEN in suits, late for work or working late, mill about, looking at their iPhones and iP ONE is shuffling through his iPod. Agnes eyes the i’S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits in the back of the moving train and looks out window as Bridgeport flies by. Trees turn the outside wor into a green blur. The TRAIN CONDUCTOR comes by.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: A ticket to Grand Central please.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: That's nineteen dollars. Agnes balks. Stares horrified.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I thought it was eight.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Are you an active duty member of the United States armed forces, or disabled or a senior?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. None of those things.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s nineteen dollars one way, off- peak hours when you purchase tickets on board. Next time buy it at the station. It’s cheaper. You could get a ten trip or a weekly.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's okay. I don’t really think they'll be a next time. She hands him a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: One way?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'll buy the return in Grand Central.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes stands in the middle of Grand Central's atrium, sta up at the golden constellations on the ceiling. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HUNDREDS OF PEOPLE jostle past her, some almost knocking over. But she can't stop staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits in the back of a yellow cab, staring out the window at the Big Bad Apple, like a tourist, moving slowl through Manhattan traffic. From time to time she looks at the meter with worry as th fare climbs mercilessly. When it gets to ten dollars, she leans forward toward THE DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Could you stop please? I’1l walk. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes crosses Washington Square taking in the fountain an the diverse crowds of STUDENTS, STREET MUSICIANS, TOURIST and THE HOMELESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes stops in front of a tiny shop window filled with puzzles on display: PUZZLEMANIA. The look in her eyes is of child-like awe. She’s arrived!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BELL RINGS as Agnes enters the cluttered shop. A HEAVIL PIERCED YOUNG MAN at the counter looks up from his phone.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Let me know if you need any help. The place is a puzzle-lover's fantasy come to life; dusty dark, almost like an old bookstore, with wall-to-wall puz of every type imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Man watches Agnes, her arms full of puzzles, agonizing between two final purchases.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What do you think, sir? Which one? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She holds up the two puzzles: a portrait of a mother bath her child (Mary Cassatt’s painting "Mother and Child") an painting of naked woman lying provocatively on a couch (Goya's "The Nude Maja").

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Uh... depends on what you want to spend days looking at.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: They're each a thousand pieces. They take forever. Agnes looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'll take both. She carries her pile of puzzles to the counter. The Young starts RINGING her up. Agnes focuses on a handwritten sign with tiny tabs hangin off the bottom on a bulletin board nearby: “CHAMPION DESPERATELY LOOKING FOR PUZZLE PARTNER”. She gazes at the sign for a while, then looks away and finds her wallet, b then her eyes land on the sign again. AGNES (CONT’D) (pointing to sign) What’s that about? “Desperately”. The Young Man turns to look at the sign.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Some guy. My father is usually here. I’m just visiting.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Is he sick?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Your dad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: No. He just had a meeting out of town.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Good. Please take good care of him. It’s devastating when they’re gone, believe me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 63 64 65 66 CONTINUED: (2) 27. 60 The Young Man stares at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: He’ll be back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying two bags of puzzles, Agnes steps out of the stor onto the sun-drenched sidewalk. She breathes the day in. turns around and steps back inside. We see her through the window, pointing at the sign on th bulletin board and talking with the Young Man.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING 62
dialogues.text: The sun sets over New York City as Agnes's train speeds n back to Bridgeport. Agnes sits near a knocked-out loaded SNORING MAN IN A SUI She's holding one of the little paper tabs from the Puzzlemania bulletin board in her hand, staring. It reads Text 646-977-7839.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes lies awake in bed; Louie is asleep next to her. SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes tiptoes into the kitchen in her nightgown with her iPhone in her hand and the Mary Cassatt’s "Mother and Chi puzzle box. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes puts puzzle pieces together with speed and efficien She’s a natural. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mother and Child" completed, Agnes gets up, moves to the other side of the table, puts the phone on the table and next to it, as if it was a typewriter. Using one finger, she touches the MESSAGES icon. Giddily, gets into text mode. She looks at the screen, unsure, the touches the WRITE icon. Then balks. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Types the phone number off the paper tab she fishes out o her nightgown pocket. Then deletes it. Then she types it again and writes: “Hi. My name is Agnes. I think I might be good at this.” After a pause she types: “Puzzles, I mean.” Then, on an impulse, she presses "SEND" and closes her ey A beat later, a response text RINGS and she opens her eye surprise. The text reads: “How good?” She giggles and sta to type back with one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes lies awake in bed next to Louie. She’s holding her phone to heart. Can’t sleep. Louie’s SNORING doesn’t help

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes kneels before FATHER KUTASH, a line of people waiti behind her. Kutash dips his thumb into some ashes and mak a small cross on Agnes's forehead. It’s Ash Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER KUTASH
dialogues.text: Remember that thou art dust and to dust thou shalt return...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes expertly hands her ticket to ANOTHER TRAIN CONDUCTO and watches while he punches it. He also has an Ash Cross his forehead, peeking from underneath his uniform hat. Sh likes that.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks down a cobblestoned street, counting numbers under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is standing in front of a beautiful but slickly contemporary townhouse. She walks up the steps. Peers into the security camera. L her finger to ring the buzzer, but before she even touche the door opens. Standing in front of her is ROBERT. Handsome, in his 50s, wearing simple but not inexpensive clothes. THE WEATHER CHANNEL IS ON TV INSIDE THE HOUSE. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm Agnes. Hi! Agnes sticks her hand out. He shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Robert. Come in. You write funny texts, Agnes. 29. 71 Agnes smiles politely and enters the house where she take off her jacket. He follows her in and closes the door beh him INT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - CONTINUOUS They stand awkwardly at the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Have you seen the news?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What? No. I-- I’m-- I'm here about the puzzles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The flood in India. Thousands of people washed away just like that. Boggles the mind. There was an earthquake in Northern Iran. I’m not trying to be gloomy. I know we're just meeting. It’s just-- Too much!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. I-- I didn’t hear-- She laughs nervously, then stops herself. AGNES (CONT’D) How are my texts funny?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What? Oh-- I'm sorry, but... you seem to have some dirt on your forehead.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. I- He reaches out to brush it off.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's Ash Wednesday. He pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, is that today?

dialogues.speaker: A72
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: All day.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Is that a problem? He smiles, she’s strange.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not at all. As long as we don’t have to share the prize with the pope. Agnes stays put, a bit stunned.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What prize? INT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - DAY Agnes nervously follows Robert to a coat closet...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You said “prize”.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Every competition has a prize. INT. LIVING ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert hangs her coat in the coat closet...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Your ad didn’t mention a prize. Robert keeps walking and Agnes follows him... INT. LIVING ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 74-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through a living room with a huge table and chandelier...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I thought it was obvious. “CHAMPION

dialogues.speaker: DESPERATELY LOOKING FOR PUZZLE
dialogues.text: PARTNER”. Did you think I was looking for companionship?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. No. Of course not. Just-- a partner. 72 73 75 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: For a competition. AGNES . . . I’ve never competed in anything in my life.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not even for the affection of your husband?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What? I-- How do you know I’m married? She realizes the ring on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Educated guess.

dialogues.speaker: AGNE,
dialogues.text: I could be a widow.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Sometimes. He laughs. 76 INT. DEN. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 76 ..-And into the perfectly-organized den/study at the back the house where a TV is on, tuned to the Weather Channel. Large magnets, plastic tubings and blueprints are piled u the desk and wall, untouched, like a museum piece. Robert opens a small door and holds it for Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: May I ask-- Why did you answer the ad? She shrugs, then looks away, embarrassed, about to say something.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, no, don’t say it?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to say you were... “puzzled by the ad.” (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She smiles uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And don’t think your smiling right now worries me any less. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert enter a beautiful mahogany puzzle suite, filled with reading lamps and lined with bookshelves and ladders leading to higher shelves, all filled with puzzle The adjoining area is a circular room where an oak table two leather chairs await the players.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sit. Please. Agnes sits down at the table. Still stunned. Robert perus one of his bookshelves, pulls a puzzle out and dumps the pieces out in front of Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right. Let's see how we work together.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (anxious ) Is this a test?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What’s the competition?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: National Jigsaw Puzzle championship. Single competition is five-hundred piece puzzles. The doubles is a thousand pieces. It’s limited to a hundred and eighty couples. I won the singles last year. My first time.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I didn’t know such a thing existed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Don’t tell anyone. There’1ll be a run on the place.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What happened to your partner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How do you know I had a partner? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You wouldn't sign up for doubles if you didn’t have a partner.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Very good. She left.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why? He takes her in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Show me how you do puzzles, then maybe I‘1l tell you. Agnes nervously starts gathering pieces and looking at th She then grabs handfuls of pieces and begins spreading th out. ROBERT (CONT’D You're not doing colors first? Agnes shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rule number one of competitive puzzling. You've got to organize by color before you do anything else. Agnes nods meekly and starts organizing by color.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll do green and the oranges. You do the red and the dark browns. They are silent for a minute as they work. Then Agnes rea for the cover to turn it and look at it for a long time. Robert sighs and pushes his chair back.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long have you been puzzling?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: A while.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How long is awhile?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m very fast.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You said that in your text. How long? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can’t remember. Years. I was always good in math. Patterns. Shapes. I just picked a puzzle up the other day and-- there it was, like riding a bike. Agnes averts her gaze. She’s lying. He takes her in. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - LATER 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert are working together in silence. They're about a third of the way through the puzzle. Robert pause watch Agnes. Her hands move rapidly; she seems to sense t a piece won't fit even before trying it. Robert raises his eyebrows, then reaches for a piece. Agn reaches for it at the same time. Their hands bump.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sorry. Pardon me. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE — LATER 79 There's only one puzzle piece left on the table. They bot stare at it hungrily, like it's the last remaining bite o cake.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Agnes picks up the piece and gleefully fits it in to comp the puzzle. She laughs out of sheer delight. Robert turns and looks at the timer. It reads 48 minutes 26 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck me! She looks at him uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pardon my French. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t get out much, do you? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And yet you came to a total stranger's door and willingly followed him in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I ask. Again. Respectfully. Why? She shrugs. Then laughs to herself.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were just tempted to say it again, weren’t you? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Get it out of your system. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s inevitable. Get out of jail free. Say it once and never again.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Your ad said “desperately”. I was... puzzled. She cracks herself up, roaring with laughter. He looks at with strange fascination. Something’s off with her, somet fascinating to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes puts her jacket on by the coat closet.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don't need to think about it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not for a minute. You’re a godsend. This was meant to be. Agnes tries hard to contain her smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What works for you? We need to meet at least twice a week. The tournament is in a month. That's barely enough time to prepare.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you can't do it now.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. I can do it. (forcefully) I'll do it. I want to. I’1l-- Yes. Wait-- He stares at her, intrigued. She’s looking away, as if do calculations in her mind. AGNES (CONT’D) Why did she leave you, your partner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: She just left. No explanation, really. Just up and gone. Not even a note.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: So she wasn’t just a puzzle partner?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. She was my wife.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Was she good? At puzzles, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Better than most. Not as good as you. She smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Okay. Mondays and Wednesdays. te herself) Mondays and Wednesdays. (to Robert) You don’t have to be at work?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I work at home.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, Louie and the boys are in the middle of dinner.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (nervously) ...I got some bad news. They all stop and look at her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aunt Emily is sick. I mean, she broke her foot, the poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: She tripped.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: So I'll be going to New Rochelle two days a week to help her out. You know, buy groceries, cook some meals for her... Mondays and Wednesdays. For about a month.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That's a long time, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You won't even notice the difference.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Should we go visit her too? AGNES GABE | ; I don't think that's I've got a lot going on this necessary. weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Should I write her a card? Agnes pats Ziggy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes. That's a nice idea. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the kitchen door we see Ziggy smoking in the back and browsing through his phone. Agnes is cleaning up. She hums to herself. Gabe is on his laptop at the kitchen tab

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (staring at the laptop) It says I have to write one essay about "why I want to go to college" and in another essay I have to describe a"transformative experience" in my life.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What does that mean? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: They all ask for it. UConn, all the SUNY schools..."why do you want to go to college?""Describe a transformative experience in your life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOORBELL RINGS and Gabe jumps up. INT. LIVING ROOM/DEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes has her feet soaking in a tub of warm water in the living room. Louie is meticulously handcrafting pieces of fishing lure. Nicki and Gabe are splayed out on the den floor looking a Gabe’s laptop. Next to them, Ziggy is watching a “Big Brother” type show on television.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about the time we went to Hungary with Grandpa?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That was me, mom. I wasn’t there mom. That was Ziggy. IT GETS QUIET FOR A LONG BEAT SAVE FOR THE REALITY SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What about the time I got sick after my father died? That was hard on all of you. They all freeze. The SOUND OF THE TV DOMINATES FOR A BEAT Nicki stares, unsure what to say. Louie pretends he isn’t listening.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I got it. When that ugly girl popped your cherry. That must have been transformative. You haven’t made sense ever since. Gabe throws a pillow at Ziggy, but misses and hits Louie.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Goddamnit. There’s a lady present.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: (to Nicki) I apologize. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: That’s okay. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m here too, Gabe. I’m a lady present.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What? Oh. Sure. Sorry, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I meant we had a guest, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Let's face it, there’s just nothing transformative in my life. Maybe I shouldn’t even go to college.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That’s not a conversation for right now.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You have to go to college.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Whatever. Louie shakes his head and goes back to his fly-fishing ba

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to herself) “Transformative” is such a funny word. Trans. Form. A. Tive. Trans. For. Mat. Ive. Trans. Format... Agnes looks up at the TV and splashes her feet in the wat making a little rhythm out of the splashing. Ziggy watche her, amused.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Why are you in such a good mood all of a sudden, Mom? Agnes looks self-conscious for a second, caught. Then she smiles and splashes her feet a little more. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m just happy we’re all together here. Right now. Like this. 40. 83 Nicki looks at her. You can see a hurt, un-parented child of a sudden. No.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Can I sleep over tonight? On the couch.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: On the couch.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What about your parents?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: They’re out of town. I feel safer here.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I could go sleep over at her place.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE AGNES
dialogues.text: No. Louie and Agnes exchange looks. Ziggy laughs. AGNES (CONT’D) I’ll get the extra blanket. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - LATER

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC BLASTING UPSTAIRS SEEPS THROUGH THE CEILING.
dialogues.text: Agnes are putting dishes away.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: She's using you. Everyone always uses you and you let them. You’re a sucker is what you are.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s called being kind.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Sucker is being kind with no filter.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: She’s my aunt.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: She has her own family. You have things to do here. We need you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 Louie and (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you. I got those invoices piling up at the garage you could help with. And, anyway, you need rest. You can’t go.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’ve rested enough. Why do you always do this?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I’m just worried about you. The doctor said-- (changing approach) Maybe I’m selfish. Okay? I admit it. I love you too much. You take such good care of us. And I want you to take it easy, is that so wrong? Let me call her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. I-- I-- I’1l call her and let her know I can’t come twice a week.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Not even once a week. For your sake, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Okay. He kisses her on the cheek and leaves; he’s done helping, point made

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie is SNORING AGAIN. Agnes lies awake, listening to hi After a second, she jabs him, with her elbow. He jumps.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Wha-? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're snoring.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (CONTINUED )
Louie moans and turns over on his side.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Relax. It’s late. Go to sleep. And then he goes back to sleep quietly.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Agnes buries herself under the covers. Louie starts SNORI AGNES (CONT’ D) (whispering td herself) I knew she wouldn’t stay on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes waits on the platform as The Metro North train ROAR into the station and comes to a full stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes hurries through the Grand Central atrium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits in a crowded subway car, nervous. A BLIND MAN stands close by, SINGING "AVE MARIA" IN AN ALMOST IMPOSSI HIGH VOICE. Agnes gets up and gives The Blind Man a dollar. EXT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. PERRY STREET. WEST VILLAGE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes nervously approaches Robert's townhouse and stops c spotting: An impatient MAN IN A SUIT RINGING ROBERT’S DOORBELL. Agnes watches him try the bell a few more times, BANG ON DOOR, then give up and walk off angry. She remains frozen in place. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then slowly Robert’s door opens. He stands there smiling motions for her to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert leads Agnes toward the den/study. MID-CONVERSATION

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: ...-I don’t open the door for the past.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I understand.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That man was a business associate of mine. I don’t have any patience for business these days. Too much pressure. And anyway, I was watching the surveillance camera footage online from the mass shooting last night. Have you seen it? It’s so goddamn awful. He stops and faces her. She lowers her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t have as much time as I thought. I’m sorry. We better start. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert dramatically dumps an entire 1000-piece puzzle out onto the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: So they give you the puzzle and you pour the whole thing out at once. You don't take little handfuls and spread them around the table. I noticed you doing that the other day. Agnes nods, seated.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You also stand up. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then you walk around the table a couple of times before you start. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They both walk around the table a couple of times, it’s awkward. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get more perspective this way. You see puzzle pieces without the glare. You see patterns you might not have seen from your Chair. Different color schemes. Agnes nods, still circling the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right. Now we can sit. They sit. Robert hits the timer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's faster to divide things up. So I'll do borders, you do colors. INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 93 Agnes and Robert are about halfway through the puzzle. Sh moving with great speed, fitting pieces into the puzzle f while sneaking peeks at the timer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Your name should actually be pronounced "Ag-NESH," right? She looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's how my father would pronounce it, yes. But I was born here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Ag-nesh Oros.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I was Mata before Oros. That’s my maiden name. Agnes Mata.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Really? Bet you’ve heard plenty of Mata Hari jokes growing up.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Not even one. She goes back to the puzzle again. Robert stops the timer then leans over and presses the intercom buzzer on the wa (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Tea, Maria. Agnes looks at him surprised. Then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s funny?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: A blind man on the train was singing “Ave Maria”.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And that’s funny how?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: “Tea, Maria.” “Ave Maria”. I don’t know. It’s ironic.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s not irony. That's coincidence. It doesn’t mean anything. AGNES ; It must mean something.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You don’t really believe that. Do you? He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come. She follows as they walk into: INT. TEA ROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - CONTINUOUS A94

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit just as MARIA, a young, pretty maid, comes in wi teetering tray full of teacups and cookies. Agnes immedia leaps up to help her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm fine, ma'am, thank you. She's fine. Agnes sits down and watches as Maria sets the cups down, pours the tea, etc. She keeps reaching out to help her, t steady things. Robert watches Agnes. When Maria leaves, Robert leans back in his chair, balanc his tea cup on his knee. Agnes takes a sip of the tea.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You like it? Agnes nods, suddenly uneasy. She bites into a cookie. IT CRUNCHES LOUDLY. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're so much more comfortable when you're focusing on the puzzle, aren't you? Agnes nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You ask a lot of questions.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's how you get to know someone.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But I don’t ask you anything.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Go ahead. She looks away, as if calculating.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can’t think of a question right now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s my point. You’re uncomfortable around me.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know you... But it’s not just you. I don’t feel comfortable, generally, because I-- She's thinking. He watches her patiently. AGNES (CONT’D) --Because normally my mind is-- I-- I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Because normally your mind is moving so fast, you don’t really know where it’s going. There’s nowhere for you to express your mind. No one to express it to. It makes you nervous. So you shut down and focus on menial tasks. Puzzles are menial tasks for you, so you can focus. But the results are aesthetically pleasing and you like it. It turns you on. She stares at him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ag4 CONTINUED: (2) 47. aA94

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Impressed?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I totally understand what you just said. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Honestly, Agnes, if you learn the rules and hone your technique, I think we have a good chance at going to Belgium. I’m not kidding here.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (shocked) Belgium?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The WJPF international competition. It’s in Brussels. Right after the nationals. Ever been? Agnes shakes her head, clearly anxious.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is that if we win the nationals we go on to the World Jigsaw Puzzle Federation competition. The color drains out of Agnes's face.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't want a free trip to the ancestral home of the Brussel sprout, Mata? Agnes shakes her head and tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: We don’t have time for tea. He looks at her as she gets up and returns to the puzzle table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (singing softly) Ave maria, gratia plena, Dominus tecum. She laughs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ag4 94 95 96 97 CONTINUED: (3) 48.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) Benedicta tu in mulieribus, et benedictus fructus ventris tui, Iesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes hurries to the subway, passing the window of a gour chocolate shop. Suddenly, she slows her steps. Stops. And turns around. She studies her reflection in the window, becoming self-conscious. Moves her hair back. Switches he bag over to the other side. Stands straight. She suddenly notices a MAN MUNCHING ON A CHOCOLATE BAR looking at her from inside the store through the glass. S turns her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating chocolate, Agnes rides the train back home, one br dress in a sea of commuter suits. She checks her watch. Shakes her head to herself. Then gets her iPhone out. Bro through it tentatively. Turns to the BUSINESSMAN sitting to her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Can you show me how Google works?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is typing on her phone. We see a Google entry: “Mat Hari”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auto body sanding and grinding is going on. We're in a small, somewhat rundown garage located on the outskirts of Bridgeport. An old sign reads: "Louie K's." Agnes's car pulls into the garage. She gets out. Louie emerges, smudged with grease.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Look who it is! He gives her a hug and a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To what do we owe the honor? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She holds out a box of chocolates.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What, are you trying to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. God. It’s just-- You've been so good.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I was kidding, Agnes. Louie takes the chocolate with his grubby hands and kisse her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I thought maybe I’1l take a look at those invoices.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Ziggy emerges.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You were coming from outside.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I was takin' a smoke break.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: So why'd you just say you were in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: That’s were I was before. You don’t want me to smoke in the bathroom, do you? The two men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small glass window looks out onto the activity in the garage below. Sitting at a messy desk, Agnes stuffs a pile of invoices (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: an envelope, scrawls something on it, then sets it aside. picks up another piece of paper, starts to put it aside, frowns and inspect it. She shakes her head to herself, looking very worried all of a sudden. Then she stands up and looks out the glass window. Louie talking to a YOUNG WOMAN who is picking up her car. She's nodding and thanking him. Then Louie cracks a joke and sh laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t understand how you can stay married to him for so long. Agnes turns around. Ziggy is there, his hands stuffed in pockets.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Your father is a decent, good man.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s what he says about you. Seriously. All the other guys flirt with the customers and he just like talks about how awesome his wife is all the time.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's nice. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Zig?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Ah...I don't know. (pause) I’m miserable. I hate my life.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, honey.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Dad hired me out of pity. And now it's been nine months.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That’s not true. Ziggy sighs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 CONTINUED: (2) 51. 98

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I'm not good at this. Do you know what it's like to spend all day not doing the thing you're good at? Agnes doesn't answer. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: So what would you rather do? What are you good at?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I don't think I’m good at anything. Agnes sighs and hugs Ziggy. He’s fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened to you, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just got lost, honey, when Grandpa died-- He was-- You know, it was just my dad and me for so Many years. I was confused. I needed a place to rest.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: You've only had men in your life.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I guess that’s true. He wipes his tears.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Can't be much of a man if I’m crying.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, Ziggy, honey, men cry! They cry more than women. But not always with tears. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I want to cook, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: You asked me what I’m good at, I don’t know. But I want to cook.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Seriously? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’ve watched you cook all my life. I watch cooking shows when no one’s home. I think I’d be happy doing what you do, not what Dad does.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But I don’t do anything.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me? You do a million things. And you're good at all of them. She smiles, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Can I ask you for a favor?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Can you show me how to work the apps on my phone?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But don’t tell Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIP HOP MUSIC PLAYS LOUDLY as EIGHT SEVENTEEN-YEAR OLDS, including Gabe and Nicki, are hanging out, some deep into XBox, some chatting, laughing, looking through a photo bo posing for iPhones snaps, drinking soda, etc.. Agnes enters from the kitchen and lays down snacks on the table.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mrs. Oros.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Does anyone need anything? No reply. She looks at Gabe. He’s busy. AGNES (CONT’D) (a bit too loud) Does anyone need anything? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 CONTINUED: 53. Everyone stares at her. She smiles to herself. 100 __ AGNES (CONT’D) I guess it’s just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Louie are brushing their teeth together, side b side, looking in the mirror at their reflections.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I feel bad that Ziggy never got to go to college. LOUIE ; He got terrible grades. Gabe is the smart one.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But still. Maybe he should've tried. Or we should've helped him try.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: We didn't have the money.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Do you ever wish you'd gone? To college, I mean? Learn things just to know them?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Nope. I would've hated it. Agnes nods and spits out her toothpaste.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I think I would have majored in math.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Math, huh? That’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Ever wonder what your life would be like if you met me a few years later. Or never met me at all?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Not for one second. I thank God I have you every day.

dialogues.speaker: ___ AGNES
dialogues.text: Every single day? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: And night. He chuckles and kisses her cheek. AGNES. I think we should watch the news.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. Just more often.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Why? Nothing good’s happening in the world.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Still. Shouldn’t we know about it? He shrugs. She rinses off her toothbrush, and then heads of the bathroom, shutting off the light as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (in the darkness) Hey! Agnes! I’m still here.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Robert smiles at her. He’s in his coat Agnes is taken aback as he steps out and closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. WE are.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Together? Where?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s a surprise. He takes her hand but she recoils.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You’1l like this one.  104 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert are sitting across from each other at a table, working on a new puzzle, the timer running. Agnes very tense and ill at ease. We move back to see the store basement lined with shelves stacked with puzzles and filled with populated tables: a collection of ODD BALLS, mostly elderly folks, all gather to puzzle together. Agnes moves uncomfortably in her seat. She’s not her usua fluid puzzler, she can’t focus. AGNES AND ROBERT WHISPER

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why we have to compete already?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What’s the big deal? Agnes shakes her head, she’s upset.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I thought we'd do this to boost your confidence.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Well, you thought wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Just focus on what I’m doing. She looks around, catches some glimpses. Gets back to the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I looked you up. I mean, I googled you. On my phone.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You’re an inventor.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Something with magnets. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I have a patent under my name. One invention. One good idea that took off. That’s it. I stumbled onto it almost by accident. Haven’t come up with anything since.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It made your very rich.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It was a fluke. I’m no inventor. Let’s just do the puzzle. She gets frustrated trying to fit a piece in. Throws it b into the box. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why are people staring at us? He stops the timer.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. This was a bad idea. I’m sorry. Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
