dialogues.text: The street is filled with golden, late afternoon sunlight Robert and Agnes exit Puzzlemania when Agnes suddenly sto takes a deep breath and turns her face up towards the moo smiling. He stares at her, moved and attracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert walk side by side. MID-CONVERSATION:

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: At the end she just didn’t like... ME. We got divorced. I never wanted kids anyway.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Frankly, I don’t like kids.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: How can you say that? You were a kid yourself once.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Right. And I hated it. Not everyone’s supposed to have kids, you know. And not only for selfish reasons. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes for the kids’ sake. In this town kids are an ornament or a fashion statement. An accessory. A checked box. I never felt a need. Does that make me weird? The PHONE IN Agnes's BAG SUDDENLY STARTS RINGING. She searches for it in panic. Answers.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Is everything okay, Ziggy? Yes. You scared me. Well, it’s my emergency phone! I’m not home right now. I’m out. Out. I’m at a church meeting. Yes, I’1l see you later. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Church?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Was that your son?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes. My oldest accessory. And no, it doesn’t make you weird. Just different from everyone I’ve ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s getting dark. Agnes hurries up the stairs over the platform where she trips and almost falls on her face. A IN A TRENCH COAT catches her by the arm. Agnes sits heavily down on the stairs and looks at her an h AGNES (sighing) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Agnes? She looks up, heart sinking to realize the Man in the Tre Coat is Ronnie, Louie’s pal we saw taking an appetizer fr her at her birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Hi. Ronnie. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She slowly lot.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Where were you just coming from?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Errands.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Your car on the fritz again?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. The car's having a bit of... yeah. No. Louie fixed it. I don't know. I felt like taking the train. Don’t you have days like that?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: If I never see another commuter train in my life I would be a very happy man. gets to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm actually running really late-

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: We got the invite.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Great. We’ll see you then.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Tell Louie I say hi.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I will. I will.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Is the ankle okay? Agnes is already limping away towards her car in the park 108 INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: along with Agnes rushes in the door to find Louie’s sister, Ezster, Louie, Gabe, Ziggy, and Nicki, all sitting around the dining room table, eating a large pizza.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Ezster. I'm so sorry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks Agnes sits eating. 59. 109

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER
dialogues.text: You missed the Ladies Guild meeting. We were worried. at Ziggy. He nods to her in reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That was today?

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER
dialogues.text: Yes it was.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I was with my Aunt Emily. In New Rochelle. I’m sorry. She had an accident, she broke her foot, and I... She needed me. There was no one else. Anyway, I was buying groceries for her, and the line was just out the door, and my emergency phone... I couldn't- (to Louie) She's my only living relative. Maybe that makes me a sucker, okay, but I had to--

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it now. Sit. Eat.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I offered to cook, but everyone was starving. at the table. Suddenly, she notices Nicki’s not

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Nicki, the cheese! You can’t eat it.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: It’s not just that. I don't eat white flour anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The bleach is just really, really bad for her stomach. Long awkward pause. Agnes pushes her chair back.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m going to make a little something for Nicki.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Who wants wine? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EZSTER
dialogues.text: No wine for me. It's Lent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes stands in the doorway and waves goodbye as Ezster waddles over to her car and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Sorry about dinner! Next time I'll-- Bye! Ezster slams the car door shut and drives away. AGNES (CONT’D) (whispering to herself) Next time I’1l just tell you to leave my house and never come back.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's that? She turns to see Ziggy stepping out of the house and ligh a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t smoke.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I--

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me. I don’t want to know. Whatever it is, I hope it’s something that makes you feel good.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s nothing like that.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you ever divorce him? Seriously? You were never truly happy.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't think a mother and son should be having a conversation like this.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Whatever. He sits on the front steps. She lowers herself next to hi (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Give me one.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: A cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes. Laughing, he gives her a cigarette and lights it for her. inhales. Starts coughing. Tries again. Coughs harder.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mom. When was the last time you had one?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: This is my first. He takes it out of her mouth and drops it on the ground. Stomps it out. AGNES (CONT’D) I love your father. I could never leave him. And I love you and I love Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I had a feeling that was going to be your answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Louie are getting ready for bed, MID-ARGUMENT:

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Well, excuse me, saint Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (angry) You can’t tell me to refuse a poor woman in need. And during Lent! It’s bad enough your sister casts an evil eye on me for missing the church meeting. I’m sorry. My aunt needed me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You're exaggerating. Ezster--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: For once, take my side! There’s so much pain all around us. So much suffering in the world. Why shouldn’t I help? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Louie shakes his head, then tousles her hair. AGNES (CONT’D) What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You lied to me. Like a child.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You denied me an act of charity. Like a heartless master.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You know exactly what it means. Shaking his head, he walks into the bathroom. Agnes watch him go in shock, breathing hard, horrified by her ever growing string of lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes's finger presses the buzzer. A second later, Robert opens the door. He's in a gorgeous silk kimono. And nothi else. Agnes turns bright red.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mata.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m early. I can come back.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, not at all. Come in. The elections are too close to call. They think there’s going to be a coup. Go ahead. I'll be right down. He quickly walks back in.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Which elections? Where? INT. DEN/STUDY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 113

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS IS ON TV.
dialogues.text: Agnes studies the photos on the wall in Robert's office: Robert in a suit, receiving an award at a banquet; Robert the cover of a business magazine, the caption reading: “What's The Next Big Thing?”; Robert and a DATE before hi high school prom; Robert with his ELDERLY PARENTS in the country. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks over the magnets, plastic tubing and blueprints Robert’s neatly organized desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was all way too premature. She turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The coup. Just rumors. They’re going to certify the elections.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (pointing to desk) Is this where you work? He smiles without answering and tightens his kimono.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Okay. (re: kimono) Do you want to change before we start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is still in his kimono. He and Agnes are facing ea other at the puzzle table. Agnes's eyes move up from the puzzle to his chest, and th back down to the puzzle again. She picks up some puzzle pieces, looking for something, a then throws them back in the box.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mata, If you've picked up a piece and looked at it, then you shouldn't put it back. You should set it aside. It'll save you time later. Remember? Agnes nods and looks at his chest again. She gets up abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  115 116 117
INT. BATHROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 115

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes sits on a chair in the middle of the white, shiny, palatial bathroom, her burning face in her hands. She tak couple of deep breaths. Then she gets up and walks over to the sink. There are do of expensive soaps and perfumes and lotions. Agnes washes her hands, tries a couple of lotions, and th spritzes some perfume on her wrist. MONTAGE. AGNES’S HALLWAY PORTRAITS 116 --Agnes walks into the hallway and stops, staring at the masks on the wall. --We move through a series of portraits of Agnes trying o three different masks from Robert’s collection in the hal mirror: happy, blank expression, sad...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling) Agnes, are we playing hide and seek? Cause I’m not sure who’s vit", INT. LIBRARY. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 117 Agnes and Robert finish up the puzzle and walk over to th tea room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria holds up a tea canister to show Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You like this one Mrs., right?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you, dear. Maria pours as Agnes turns back to Robert to resume their conversation:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kesz.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Done. Finished. Maria places the teas in front of them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGNES (CONT’D) Thanks, Maria. Maria smiles and exits. Agnes winces and rubs her

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I hunch over and I--

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You need to do some yoga. Agnes shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why not? He gets out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how to do Sun Salutations?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yoga is for little anorexic girls. Robert laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Get up, Mata. Robert stands there, hands on hips.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get up. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hands above your head. AGNES. . I’m not taking instructions from a man in a red kimono.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hands above your head. She obeys.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now lean back. Agnes tries to lean back.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Eeee. Ow. 65.

dialogues.speaker: A118
dialogues.text: shoulder. Robert gets behind her and starts massaging her shoulder. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you do--?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now open your arms out in a circle and let them fall to your sides. I’ve been doing this for ten years. She opens her arms out in a circle and lets them fall to sides

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. He keeps rubbing her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever had a professional massage?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. Not really. A tiny moan starts to escape her lips, but she stops hers

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'd like to buy you a massage. You won't believe what a difference it- Agnes suddenly walks out of the tea room and back to her chair where she picks up her bag. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: If I want a massage I can buy one myself. I'm not a-- I'm not a bag lady or a--

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Agnes--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Come on, Agnes. Don't get weird on me.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It's three already. I can’t be late getting home.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: If you want, I’1l come to your home next time.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'll see you here Monday. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 CONTINUED: (3) 67.

dialogues.speaker: A118
dialogues.text: Robert regards her as she leaves. AGNES (0.S.) (CONT’D) And next time put on some real clothes for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes crawls in bed with Louie. They lie facing each othe Louie reaches out to caress her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: When I was at your office, doing paperwork... I saw one of the bank statements.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I told you we had a bad year.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me it was that bad. We don't have enough to send Gabe to college. Now he's gonna need a full scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Well, what am I supposed to do about it? I'm working my ass off.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: We could sell the land in Ellenville.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: That's... no. That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Because fishing is the most important thing in my life! Agnes sits up in bed and looks at him, her eyes burning.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Fishing is the most important thing in your life?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Agnes. You know what I mean.  119 120 68. INT. BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 119 Agnes lies awake in bed as the first sun rays caress the room. She listens to LOUIE SNORE.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (whispering) Five. Four. Three. Two. One. Her IPHONE ALARM GOES OFF. She turns to face Louie.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: _ (groggy), Five more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Take an hour or two. He opens his eyes in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What? INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 120 Agnes walks into the kitchen in her nightgown, bleary-eye and stops short. Ziggy is standing at the stove, frying eggs and making ba

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What are you doing up already?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: What does it look like?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I was going to do that.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Well, today I’m doing it. You can relax. I bought truffle oil at this imported goods store and I want to try it in the eggs. Agnes sits down at the kitchen table, and watches Ziggy c for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are you gay, Ziggy? He turns around and gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s okay if you are. Your father will understand.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I am. I’m just not very--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Experienced?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Interested. 121 INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - LATER 121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, Ziggy, Louie, and Gabe sit around the table, eatin beautifully cooked breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: This is really good. Ziggy beams. Louie, his mouth full, nods enthusiastically

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: It’s the truffle oil.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Isn't that chocolate?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: (laughing) No. Mushrooms. Agnes stares blankly at her husband from across the table looks back at her worried. She recognizes the look, recov and smiles at him. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to Ziggy) We better skedaddle or we’ll be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes rings the doorbell. Robert opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hey--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t want to hear anything tragic right now. Thank you very much. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She pushes past him into the hallway. He looks after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is putting a puzzle together with a furious, almost inhuman speed. Robert watches her for a beat, impressed. then picks up a puzzle piece.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Don't even try. It's not going to fit. We're wasting time.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just watch you do it then?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Do what you want.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I was kidding.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Don’t kid with me. I don’t have a sense of humor. Never have. Never will. That’s why we get along. All you care about is disasters.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s... actually funny.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzle just finished, Agnes stands up and gathers her thi

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Stay and have a drink with me.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have to beat traffic. My husband and I are going fishing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I would have never guessed you liked fishing.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't. He does. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Can I come? I love fishing! It relaxes the mind.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Don’t say that. Fishing is vile.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I always throw them back in. I fish for sport not food.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, God, the world’s gone mad. She walks out of the room. Robert watches, amused. He waits a puzzle box

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (calling after her) I'll miss you, Mata. beat before following Agnes into the adjoining room. She turns to him, furious.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Because I meant it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: How can you mean it? How can this be happening?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why are we wasting all this time doing puzzles?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What else is there to do?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s a childish hobby for bored people.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You know that’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Tell me you’re not a bored rich guy. Tell me I’m not a childish housewife.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s not what we are. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 CONTINUED: (2) 72. 124

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You have much more important things to do. You're a man of ideas. Why do you do these stupid puzzles? He hesitates. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s a way to control the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. My life was never in chaos before the puzzles. Now-- ROBERT — Come on, Mata! You’re missing the point.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Okay. What’s your point, Robert?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Life is messy. It doesn’t make any goddamn sense. Sorry to break the news to you. Life’s just random. Everything is... random: my success, you here now, your kids, your life... There’s nothing we can do to control anything. And then it ends. (laughing) Painfully usually, full of regrets. She listens attentively.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But when you complete a puzzle, when you finish it, it’s like -- you know that you’ve made all the right choices. No matter how many wrong pieces you tried to fit into the wrong place, at the very end everything makes one perfect picture. I know it sounds simplistic but-- Why would I ever want to deny myself that kind of feeling? What other pursuit can give you that kind of perfection? Faith? Ambition? Wealth? Love? She studies his face, moved.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not even love can do that, Mata. Not neatly, not completely. A long beat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're hiding.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Really? Who am I hiding from?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're hiding from your real life. He smiles, as if caught. She takes him in.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’m-- She suddenly grabs his face and pulls him into a long, passionate kiss. Then she flees the scene of her crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Louie drive along a tree-lined two lane highway Agnes in the passenger seat. Louie SINGS ALONG TO THE POWER ROCK BALLAD ON THE RADIO a pounds out a drumbeat on the steering wheel. Agnes stares the window, smiling, her mind elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Louie stand in the knee-length grass of their p of land in Ellenville. There's a little falling-apart cab in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Breathe it in, Agnes. This is what it’s all about. Agnes breathes in. Then coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Louie sit on a dock by a lake. Louie is fishing Agnes takes her foot out of her shoe and dips her toe in water. Louie looks at her for a long time. MID-CONVERSATI

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I'm not saying we’re selling it. I'll just give it a thought. At my own pace. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're the big boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks out into the knee-high wet grass, her arms wrapped around her shoulders, shivering in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Agnes! What are you doing? Agnes keeps walking, farther into the grass, away from th cabin. Eventually she stops.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Agnes! She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie and Agnes sit around a campfire by the lake, eating fish.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Husband catches fish, wife cooks fish... That’s how God intended it to be. No computers, no TV, no phones... Tomorrow Tarzan go hunt for boar. Feed Jane.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Jane doesn’t want to eat a boar. Louie pours some more wine for both of them. Raising his glass:

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: To my girlfriend. Agnes raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: To my husband. He laughs. They clink glasses. Keep eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie and Agnes have sex on their sleeping bags by the ca fire, missionary and lustful and totally at ease; two peo who know each other’s bodies completely. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 131 132 CONTINUED: 75. 130 Suddenly he stops and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Nothing’s wrong. Everything's perfect just like this. He kisses her and they keep going at it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: My back. The ground is so hard. He turns her around clumsily.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ouch. Careful. My-- She starts laughing. They keep kissing with her on top no AGNES (CONT’D) We're not kids anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie and Agnes load up the back of the pickup truck. Agn face is stoney but she’s frantic. There's something diffe about her now; something confused and shut down.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Honey. What’s going on? You not feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I just want to go. Can we go now? She gets into passenger side of the pickup truck, shuttin the door. INT. LOUIE’S PICKUP TRUCK. MOVING - DAY 132 Driving, Louie chuckles, then starts giggling uncontrolla It builds into full-on laughter. Agnes stares at him insulted. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It's not funny. This only makes Louie laugh harder. AGNES (CONT’D) All these years, everyone saying there’s something wrong with me. No. There’s something wrong with you. Stop laughing! He starts shaking silently, holding back his laughter. Un he finally calms down. She turns away from him and watche the trees passing by.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: It just took me by surprise, I guess. That’s all. You've never been the competitive type and I thought... I thought it was funny. I-- It’s cute. They drive quietly for a bit, just the RADIO PLAYING CLAS PROG ROCK.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I just don’t think the excitement would be good for you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m doing it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Honey-- She turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m not asking you, I’m telling you. I’m finally doing something on my Own and you can support me or not, but I'll do it either way. I don't want to talk about it anymore. Louie’s anger rises but he keeps it in check, staring at road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: How big is it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Five hundred pieces.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Not the puzzle. The competition.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: About three hundred and sixty in the individual competition. He nods to himself over and over.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to sign up with you and do the couples competition together?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No. I’m doing it by myself.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Do what you want. I give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and the other members of the Ladies Guild (Ezster, Fanny, et al) stand in an informal assembly line and put different foodstuffs in charity Easter baskets. Agnes keeps putting canned sausage in the baskets, one ba after another, expressionless, looking at the new childre drawings on the wall. The Other Woman around her are chatting and laughing. Father Kutash walks over.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER KUTASH
dialogues.text: Confession, Agnes? She considers him. Then shakes her head and keeps working INT. GABE'S BEDROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 134 Agnes is making Gabe's bed. She spots something lying on desk, walks over and looks at it. It's a printout of his college application essay, entitled “WHY I WANT TO GO TO COLLEGE” .

dialogues.speaker: DAY 135
dialogues.text: Agnes sits next to the window, reading Gabe’s essay.  136 137 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert stand in his gorgeous kitchen, facing an incredible array of teas in a rack on the wall. Robert is holding a box under her nose. She does.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Smell it. She’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It's a mix of rose petals and bergamot. Smell this one. He opens another box. Agnes leans into smell it. He watch her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like it? Agnes nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want to try it?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Where’s Maria?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Visiting family.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is unfolding the paper Agnes just handed him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Second paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Uh... let's see. (reading out loud) "My mother doesn't know anything about the world outside of our house, our church, our traditions and our family. She, like my father and brother, never went to--" He looks up at her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He spelled “college” wrong. It says “collage”. Probably the spell- check...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (reading) "I love my mother, but I_also feel bad for her. She’s a sheltered person and doesn't think of gnything but serving the men in her e. A child of Hungarian timigrents, she lost her mother when she was young and grew Up doting on her dad. She’ g stil living in the house he raised her in. When he died after a long illness, she fell apart. She was treated for emotional problems and has never been the same from what I remember. I want to_be different. I want to go to-- collage -- and learn about other cultures, not post my own, and other ways of eing. I want to travel. I want to gain self-awareness and be sane. I want to_try new religions. New foods. I don’t want to just become ny father, who is too scared to think outside the box, or m mother, who Just won't let herself come alive." He puts the essay down. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He does say he loves you. She turns away and looks at the spice rack on the counter Agnes read

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's smart of him. College admissions love kids who are first generation to attend college. He's totally exploiting that. Very savvy. s the description on a tea box.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Mata. To me this all just rings false. It doesn't sound like you at all. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (working on puzzle) I think it sounds exactly like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disagree. You--

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You don't know me.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Hey. Robert gently puts a finger under her chin and tilts it u she's looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. I know that you're the best puzzler I've ever met. And I know that you're modest and funny and beautiful and strange. And I happen to know you’re an excellent kisser. They look at each other for a long time. She closes her e as if she’s too overwhelmed to see him or be seen.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't know why-- I don't understand why someone like you would ever find me interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: That’s exactly why. Because you don’t understand. Agnes's keeps her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Hungarian accent) Agnesh. She smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Agnesh. Can I--? Can I kiss you back now?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Please, don’t!

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON 138
dialogues.text: Agnes sits in the window on the train heading back to Bridgeport. It pulls up to the New Rochelle train station Agnes glances out the window absentmindedly. Then, after second thought, she grabs her purse and dashes out the do  139 140 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is standing at the stove in a dank, dirty little kitchen, making a grilled cheese sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: ..-And I just feel terrible that I wasn't able to come visit you any sooner! Agnes flips the grilled cheese sandwich onto a plate and carries it into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AUNT EMILY, 90, a tiny woman with a shock of white hair, in an armchair with her foot in a cast on which names and kids drawings have been magic-markered. Agnes puts the pl on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMILY
dialogues.text: I have plenty of people looking in on me. It’s like Grand Central station in here sometimes with grand kids and great grand kids. She points to the colorful drawings and signatures on her cast. AUNT EMILY (CONT’D) I keep getting names wrong. So, this helps this old lady. Agnes smiles as she sits down across from Aunt Emily and watches her eat. AUNT EMILY (CONT’D) How are you, Agnes?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Me? I'm... I feel-- I’m different.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMILY
dialogues.text: Different how?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m... Not good. But not bad at all. In between. Emily nods; she’s not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Louie? She trails off. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s the same. I'm just-- all of a sudden--

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMILY
dialogues.text: Sometimes that happens. I got mad at your Uncle Laszlo about the same things for fifty years. I would scream and scream at him. Same thing, every day. Then one day I stopped and started laughing all of a sudden. It didn’t matter anymore. I forgot what I was yelling about.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I always thought you two had a great marriage.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, we did. We did. Like you. She smiles at Agnes, then yawns and takes her dentures ou

dialogues.speaker: AUNT EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, enough chit-chat. Feel like helping me take a bath? INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 141 Agnes is busy prepping dinner, a distracted look on her f while Ziggy and Louie drink beer and Gabe hangs out.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Her parents are jerks. They grounded her for a month, but then they went on a cruise. So now her step sister is watching her, like a warden.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: A warden doesn’t watch the prisoners. The guards do.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Same difference. She’s in jail and I have to break her out. Louie gets up and opens the fridge, looking through it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: My manchego isn't in the cheese drawer. Agnes bites her lip and closes her eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I didn’t go grocery shopping today. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Too bad. I was dying for a piece of that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (snapping) I said I'm sorry. I'll buy it tomorrow. Jesus! The boys and Louie fall silent and stare at Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Gabe) What are you looking at? Can't you do something?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Like why don't you set the table for once? Ziggy helps when he can. Why are you the prince in this family? Gabe raises his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 142

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is seated around the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: So I got into the tournament. I signed up.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Oh good. You took my advice. Agnes looks at him incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the boys) Your mom's gonna be in a puzzle competition.

dialogues.speaker: . AGNES
dialogues.text: Jigsaw puzzles.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What happens if you win? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: If you win. What do you get? Is there a prize?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. I don’t know. I think you win a trophy or something. Something small. Ziggy raises his beer.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: To Mom! Gabe raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: To Mama! Louie raises his beer.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: To Mom. And her competition. They all clink their drinks. Agnes is touched.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your mother and I have something else we want to tell you. We're selling the land in Ellenville.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: And we want to give the money to you two. Gabe, to help to pay for education. Ziggy, we want you to be able to get your own place when you're ready. Maybe put a payment down on a house. Agnes looks at Louie, confused.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Lou, when did we--?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Wait, seriously? Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: _ LOUIE
dialogues.text: It's no joke. We're absolutely serious. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: But don't you guys want to use the money for yourselves? Take a vacation or something? Mom, you barely leave the house. Agnes is upset.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (firmly) It's for you two. It’s a gift. End of story.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I think it's a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is lying in bed with her eyes closed while Louie cl in next to her. He leans over and kisses her on the cheek trying to initiate some kind of physical contact.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't understand how you could make a decision like that without me.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: It was your idea!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But the last time we talked you said you'd think about it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: And I did think about it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But we didn't even get to discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Why do we need to discuss it? It’s what you wanted. Agnes rolls over onto her side, facing away from him.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I don't understand what the fucking problem is.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: The fucking problem is my fucking husband thinking there’s no fucking problem.  144 86. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 144

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ziggy is making pancakes while Agnes scrambles eggs. He skillfully flips a couple of perfect-looking pancakes. Ag peers over, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Those are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Louie comes in.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Ag, a couple of people told me they haven't gotten an invitation to the Easter Party yet.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That's strange. I mailed them all.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I’m helping Mom cook for the party.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Okay. (to Agnes) And don't forget to buy my cheese. He sits at the table just as Gabe stumbles in and drops t chair. Agnes takes the frying pan off the stove and start serving the eggs. Ziggy serves pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: So-- Hey. Guess what, everyone. Good news. I've decided what I want to do with the Ellenville money. All eyes are on Gabe. He bangs a drum roll on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: That money is for college.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I'm_ going to take a year off and go to Tibet with Nicki. Agnes stops short. Louie stares.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll go to college eventually. I just want some time to figure out what- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Dad said that money was for a house for Ziggy and your college.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: He said it was a gift. Agnes looks at Louie.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Are you going to say anything?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Travel is a kind of education unto itself.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Louie.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I did say it was a gift. Upset, Agnes puts the frying pan down on the table and st out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What’s her fucking deal?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is reading a book in bed, watching volcanic erupti on the Weather Channel. His PHONE RINGS. 152 EXT. BACKYARD. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 152

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is lying on her back in the grass, looking at the m in the sky, her iPhone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello? She hesitates. Not sure what to say. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi. WE CUT BACK AND FORTH BETWEEN AGNES’S BACKYARD AND ROBERT

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mata. Hi. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's up? Agnes closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Happy Holy Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is it Thursday already?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Holy Thursday. Tomorrow is Good Friday. Then Sunday is Easter. The resurrection.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I know what Easter is, Mata. I also know that you’re not the believer you once were. And that’s okay. You have to be kind to yourself. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I like it when you call me Mata.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s who you are.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It was... It used to be. What are you doing right now? Robert sits up in his bed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing, really. As usual. 88. 152 She laughs. Then she puts her hands over her eyes, as if remembering something terrible.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: God. That's the worst thing I've ever done.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait, what? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Kissing you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh. Wow. If that's the worst thing you've ever done, Agnes, you're pretty damn lucky. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I haven't gone to confession. I don’t know how to confess this-- I’ve been telling lies. ROBERT ; You’re not lying at all. Everything you say is true.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (impulsively) I love you. Agnes quickly ends the call, regretting. Then she slowly to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes cruises down the aisles of her local supermarket, selecting food and Easter supplies. --She puts a carton of eggs in her cart... --Then an Easter egg dyeing kit... --A bag of green plastic grass... --Some chocolate rabbits and Cadbury Creme Eggs... --At the cheese section, Agnes gets manchego cheese. Thin it over. Puts it back. --Agnes waits as the GROCERY CLERK scans her groceries. B BEEP. BEEP. BEEP. It's the same old routine, but now she no patience for it.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 154
dialogues.text: EXT. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 155 Agnes stabs the dirt with the statues to get them firm in ground. Then she walks out into the street to get a good at her work. She puts her hands on her hips and regards h house and the decorations out front. There's a new kind o critical distance in her eyes, nostalgia too. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 156

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears running down her face, Agnes holds an egg in a wire spoon, dips half of it in a bowl of blue dye, and then di the other half in a pool of red dye. Finally Agnes pushes the eggs aside, and takes out the unopened puzzle portraying Goya's The Nude Maja. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stares at the cover for a second-- it's a provocative sensual painting-- and then rips off the plastic and the cover and dumps the puzzle pieces out onto the table. INT. DINING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - SUNSET 157 Louie and Ziggy enter through the front door, and find Ag just where we left her. The Nude Maja puzzle is almost do Agnes looks up at them in a fog.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Where’s dinner? She looks up, confusion in her eyes, as if not sure where is.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I guess I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You FORGOT to make dinner? What else did you forget? Did you forget us? Agnes stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'll start making it in five minutes. I'm sorry. Louie sighs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Did you buy my cheese? Agnes doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You forgot that too.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (laughing) I did.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You think it’s funny? Agnes stares at Louie, as if challenging him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Dad! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I slave all day for this family and you're sitting around doing puzzles! Agnes gives him a look, and then goes back to The Nude Ma Her hand hovers over the puzzle board. Louie stares shock

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna make dinner for everyone. Okay? Dad. Go upstairs and take a shower. I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: No. This is bullshit. Louie bolts toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: If you leave, don’t come back. Louie freezes. Ziggy sighs and leans against the doorway, watching his mother fit the last piece of the puzzle in. Louie watches her too, unsure what to say or do. Agnes looks up at Louie, a tiny smile on her face. AGNES (CONT’D) It's done. I’1l1 make dinner now, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes, Louie, Ziggy, Gabe and Nicki sit around the table, eating pasta.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: A third of the population, something like 32% of India, live below the international poverty line. That’s $1.25 per day. How is anyone expected to survive like that? I mean, basic needs. Shelter. Food. Clothes. A long pause of pondering and/or awkwardness. Everyone ea (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (re: pasta) This is pretty good, Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I've been thinking. Ziggy. All eyes are on Agnes. AGNES (CONT’D) Maybe instead of getting your own place, you could go back to school. Maybe culinary school. ; LOUIE ; Culinary school? You want him to be a cook? 92. 158 Ziggy, Gabe and Nicki watch like spectators at a tennis match.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: He’s clearly good at it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You think it's a bad idea?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Frankly, I don’t think it’s a very manly thing to do, is what I think.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: All the great chefs today are men.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Most.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to Nicki) No one asked you. Nicki recoils.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Most of the great chefs are men. Many.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I looked it up. Online. Gabe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yes! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to Gabe) Stay out of this!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (re: Gabe) I think that if this little punk is going to Tibet, Ziggy should do whatever he wants with that money. Ziggy grins.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Punk?

dialogues.speaker: _ LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to Ziggy) You don’t want to work in the garage anymore? Ziggy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to study... cooking? Ziggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cat’s got your tongue? Ziggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Agnes) You turned my eldest son against me.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: No, Dad. It’s what I want. It was my idea. Mom’s just trying to-- Louie stares at Ziggy, disgusted. Then he gets up and lea the table.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Don’t wait up for me. He walks out. A beat later, we hear the FRONT DOOR OPEN A SLAM. INT. LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is puzzling by the lamplight. She hears the front door open, and then a few seconds lat Louie appears in the living room doorway, drunk. They exchange looks before Agnes continues doing her puzzle. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Who gave you permission to turn my son against me? He’s a man.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You're drunk. Go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Goddammit, Agnes. You've forgotten how to listen. I’ve never done you wrong. Ever. Louie takes the puzzle and hurls it across the room. It shatters, the puzzle pieces flying across the floor. Agnes's face crumples and she sinks to the floor and craw around, collecting the pieces. Louie watches her, horrifi

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Look at you. Agnes keeps collecting the pieces and pushing them back i the box.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Who’s putting all these new ideas in your head? Selling the land. Cooking school. The puzzles. Fucking competition. She ignores him and keeps looking for the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what my father would do to my mother in a situation like this? He grabs her and pins her against the wall, lifts his han if to hit her. She watches in horror. He freezes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what he would do. I never did. I’m not him. I never will be. I’m not him. And he walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to herself) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes looks out of the window at the approaching New York City skyline. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN ANNOUNCER, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Next stop, Grand Central. Next and last stop Grand Central Terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her way to the basement, Agnes notices Robert’s desk i now messy, blueprints, magnets, batteries and plastic tub laid out. Clearly he’s been getting back to his work. She smiles to herself, somehow it feels like a small triumph. She hears a LOUD POP, like a gun shot, and jumps. Turns around swiftly to see: Robert with a champagne bottle in his hand. He’s just pop the cork.

dialogues.speaker: / ROBERT
dialogues.text: Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is pouring champagne into two glasses. He and Agne are sitting across from each other at the puzzle table.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: To our last practice together. They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: To you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: To a great Good Friday. She laughs. They clink again.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: To getting all the wrong pieces right. They clink again and the champagne sloshes out of Agnes's glass. AGNES (CONT’D) I feel drunk and I haven't even taken a sip yet.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're so beautiful. Agnes looks down and blushes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's start. He dumps the puzzle out onto the table. Just as he does t Agnes clumsily leans across the table and kisses him. He kisses her back. They both stand up, embracing, puzzle pieces falling off the table. INT. BEDROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - AFTERNOON 163

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert lie under the covers together, post-coit

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I decorate the whole house, I make a turkey, we have an Easter Egg hunt... Louie's family comes early. Then all his friends from the garage. And all the women from the Ladies Guild.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What would happen if you didn't go?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: People would still show up, right? And your husband would have to entertain them. Agnes thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And maybe that would be all right.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can't imagine it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Stay here. Don't go to the party. He strokes her arm while she gazes out the window. Then s turns to him and touches his face; his eyelids, his nose, lips.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I can’t stay.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I know. That’s okay. They kiss.  97. INT. BEDROOM. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE - EVENING 164 The sun shimmers down behind a distant building and disappears. Agnes sleeps in bed next to Robert. HER PHONE RINGS INSID HER PURSE. She suddenly wakes up, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh, God. He’s going to kill me. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 165 Agnes enters quietly through the back door, then stops sh when she sees Louie at the kitchen table. He's sitting there, very still, surrounded by party detri Agnes flinches, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Look, I-

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Please don't make any excuses, Agnes. Please. I know you weren't with Emily. I called her. And Ronnie was here. Said he saw you at the train station the other day.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I was stuck in-

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Please don't lie to me. Just please don't lie to me. Please, don’t-- Louie takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to tell me. You have to tell me everything, Ag. Agnes regards him, her mood darkening.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I don’t have to tell you anything. I’m not your servant. You don’t own me. Louie gets up from the table and starts walking out of th room. AGNES (CONT’D) But I will tell you this-- He turns to face her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AGNES (CONT’D) Don't make decisions about the family without me. Don't laugh at me when I care about something. Quit telling me I'm cute all the time when you actually mean I’m dumb. Help me shop if you want your cheese. Stop looking at me like I’m damaged goods or a head case. Stop snoring! I can’t sleep at night. And never ever, ever raise a hand on me again. Louie is very still.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear any of that? Louie nods, stoic.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Are you having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes. I am. I think.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: You think you’re having an affair?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I have a puzzle partner. He’s a man. We’re a team. We’re competing as a team. We’ve had... sex. One time. And it wasn’t good but it wasn’t bad. He nods to himself. AGNES (CONT’D) Do you have anything to say? Louie hesitates, lets out a strange little laugh, then sh his head no, and starts trudging up the stairs to bed. Ag collapses against the wall, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louie enters the bedroom, sits still on the edge of the b and takes a series of long breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is on the floor, breathing hard, distraught.  167 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole family sits in a full pew and listens to the Fa Kutash deliver the Easter Sermon:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER KUTASH
dialogues.text: We began our celebration today with a service of light which represents Jesus Christ rising from the dead and bringing light to us. Christ light has shone in the world, scattering darkness forever. We had been waiting for this moment from the beginning. We heard in our readings today an account of the creation of man. And woman. This was in God’s eternal plan for humankind. But the high point is the resurrection; it is the greatest celebration of God's Church. This day is the most blessed of all as we heard in the Exsultet, the Easter Proclamation. “Rejoice, let Mother Church also rejoice!” Agnes and Louie keep glancing in each other’s direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family exits the church amid the WORSHIPPERS. Louie starts to peel off.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: (avoiding eye contact) I'm gonna go to the garage and do a little work.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Do you want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Nah. Thanks. Agnes and the boys watch Louie trudge away down the sidew his hands jammed into his pockets. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 169 Agnes and Gabe sit at the kitchen table while Ziggy stand the stove, making grilled cheese sandwiches for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Oh, and I also made these little tarts last night, these little mushroom goat cheese things... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sage? Ziggy serv She nods. 100. 169

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: From scratch?!

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And everyone loved them. Oh, and I roasted the turkey in a different way. I used sage, too.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES GABE
dialogues.text: It was really good.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What did Ezster say? About me not showing up?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I dunno. She said something to Dad and then he got mad and told her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. es them sandwiches. They all eat.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: There's this school in New York City. It's not that expensive but it's really well-known. You can get a degree in two years. And if it was okay with you guys I would keep living here and commute and then I'd still have a little money left over at the end. I don't know how long the commute would be, though. It might be too long.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Just an hour forty to Grand Central.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Really? That's it?

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's not bad. Gabe looks at Agnes curiously.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It'll be cheaper if you buy a monthly.  170 171 172 173 174 175 101. INT. BATHROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - DAY 170

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes carefully applies mascara and a coat of lipstick wh looking in the mirror. It's the first time we've seen her dolled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes rings the doorbell. Robert answers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Ready? Agnes shakes her head no. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black town car drives down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town car pulls in front of a flashy, decked-out casin with a sign out front that reads: WELCOME PUZZLERS. Robert jumps out and runs to Agnes's door. He opens it. S looks at him in panic. He offers her his hand. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be here. This isn’t me. He gingerly takes her hand and leads her out of the car. lets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert enter the lobby. They walk through the casino floor toward an entrance to an atrium where they s in at the Puzzle competition registration table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes and Robert sit down across from each other at a fol table, surrounded by HUNDREDS OF OTHER PEOPLE at identica folding tables. We catch glimpses of just a few of their fellow puzzle Competitors: --AN OVERWEIGHT COUPLE in matching cowboys suits... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: --AN OLDER WOMAN with half a dozen medals from previous competitions hanging around her neck... --Lots of KOOKY OVERDRESSED MATRONLY TYPES... --An OLDER MAN with a floor-length beard and a paper crow that says: PUZZLE KING. --A WOMAN wearing an American Flag sweater. --A COUPLE OF NERDY TEENAGERS. A WOMAN comes by and puts a paper bag full of puzzle piec and a cardboard box on their table. Agnes reaches out to touch it but Robert stops her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (softly) Not yet, honey. She stares, shaken by that last word.

dialogues.speaker: PUZZLE EMCEE
dialogues.text: Alright, Puzzlers, this is it. The moment of truth is upon us. Ready? On my count: Five. Four. Three. Two. One. BEGIN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes dumps out the pieces and starts sifting through the with her fingers. Robert, along with EVERYONE ELSE IN THE ROOM, has stood u and is walking around the table, looking at the puzzle pieces.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (whispering) What are you doing? Stand up! Agnes shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember? It's important to step away and take a-

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Shhh. I'm working. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's rapidly separating the puzzle pieces into groups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is now sitting across from Agnes and they're worki quickly, silently. He glances over her work.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're not doing it by color. She nods and continues working.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're doing it the old way. Agnes. What are you-?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Everyone else is doing colors and borders.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yes! That's how we trained!

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: If we do it that way we won't win. We'll come in second or third. I'm doing it the old way.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: If we argue about this we definitely won't win.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You're a goddamn rebel is what you are. She looks up for a quick second, smiling. She likes the i of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is standing in a corner of Robert's big white bathr making a call from her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello. Is this an emergency?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes. Hi. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I won.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO, PHONE)
dialogues.text: I left a roasted chicken in the fridge. You can just heat it up and-

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. We can take care of ourselves. Tears unexpectedly spring into Agnes's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Okay. Love you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: You wanna talk to Dad?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, no, that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Thanks baby. He hangs up. Agnes just stands there in the bathroom for second, in pain. Suddenly, A KNOCK ON THE BATHROOM DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mata, are you in there? I need your date of birth.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m on the phone booking tickets to Brussels. Do you have a frequent flier number with American? She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: 180-182 OMITTED 180-182
dialogues.text: 183 184 105. INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 183 Agnes tiptoes into the dark kitchen. She takes off her sh and leaves them by the door with the trophy. INT. LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 184 Agnes tiptoes through the dark living room towards the stairs. Suddenly she stops in her tracks and SCREAMS, groping aro in the dark and finally collapsing in a chair. A lamp turns on. It's Louie. He’s been sleeping on the co Agnes is illuminated, sitting in an armchair and cradling bare foot.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What happened? Agnes shakes her head, unable to speak. Louie comes close

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me see. Is it a splinter?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (gasping) It hurts like hell. Louie crouches down in front of Agnes and holds his hands out. After a second, she gives him her foot. He inspects

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: It looks like a piece of glass. A piece of porcelain or something. It’s tiny. He tries to touch it. Agnes yelps.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. Agnes turns the bottom of her foot up and looks at it. An she realizes:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It's the last piece.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Of what? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Of that plate you broke. On my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Hold on a second. He gets up and leaves the room. We stay on her face. Louie comes back with a pair of tweezers, a bag of cotton balls, and a bottle of rubbing alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we go. He kneels down in front of Agnes again.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now tell me if anything hurts. Agnes nods, biting her lip. Louie whistles slowly while h works.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ooh... Getting closer... That doesn't hurt? Agnes shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah ha... little bugger... It's almost out... Agnes studies Louie's face. It's full of concentration an tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: tearing up) Ready?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pull it out. It may hurt. Ready for me? She nods. 185 INT. KITCHEN. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 185 Ziggy is cooking breakfast. Gabe inspects Agnes's trophy.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s kind of small.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I got some gift certificates for puzzles too. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THE FRONT DOOR OPENS OFF SCREEN, THEN SLAMS. Gabe jumps u and goes to see what's going on. A beat later he comes ba

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Dad left for work.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY
dialogues.text: Without me?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Dal Ziggy looks at Agnes, who smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: ZIGGY,
dialogues.text: Why are you smiling?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: It’s his way of saying you can go to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pickup truck travels down a country road. INT. LOUIE’S PICKUP TRUCK. MOVING - DAY 186 Agnes drives west on the highway to Ellenville. Ziggy is riding shotgun. Nicki is squeezed in the back with Gabe; reads out loud to everyone from one of her Shambhala book

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: “All worldly pursuits have but one unavoidable and inevitable end, which is sorrow. Acquisitions end in dispersion; buildings in destruction; meetings in separation; births in death. Do not dwell in the past, and do not dream of the future. One of Buddha's students asked him: "Are you the Messiah?" "No," answered Buddha. "Then you are a healer," said the student. "No," the Buddha replied. "Then you are a teacher," the student persisted. "No, I am not a teacher," said the Buddha. "Then what are you," the student asked, exasperated. "I am awake," said the Buddha.”

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: My father was the most charming, impossible man. Nicki looks up from the book. Gabe and Ziggy stare tensel Agnes. No one says anything. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing) You would have loved him, Nicki. pause) Keep going, dear. Gabe and Ziggy exchange relieved looks.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: I feel carsick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is cleaning out the cabin together, clearing out the old debris and furniture. Agnes is carrying a big box out to the car.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Careful, Mom. Can I help? She shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabe unearths a mid-80s Frogger-type video game contrapti from under a pile of toys. He presses the play button over again over again, and eve time the VIDEO GAME THEME SONG PLAYS he and Ziggy and Nic dance to it. Agnes stands on the cabin's front porch, watching them through the screen door, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks by herself through the tall grass, towards th creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suns sets over Agnes standing in a pair of galoshes i the middle of the creek.  191 192 193 109. INT. DEN. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - SUNSET 191

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is at his desk connecting tubing and magnets. His PHONE RINGS. He recognizes the number and answers quickly ROBERT 47° PHONE ) Are you all packed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's on the phone, still standing in the middle of the creek.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I'm with my family.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: But you’re ready, right?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Do you want me to send the car?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No. I’1l take the train.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mata, you have to get to the airport at least three hours early for an international flight. You should be here around one. Security's going to take forever. Did you tell Louie?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Are you going to?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Are you going to flake on me, Mata?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: (laughing) No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Good. I love you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I miss you.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (TO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I miss you too. INT. LOUIE’S PICKUP TRUCK. MOVING - NIGHT 195

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ziggy drives. Gabe and Nicki are asleep in the back seat. Agnes gazes out the window at the passing night.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 196-197
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM. AGNES AND LOUIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 198

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes walks down the stairs to find Louie sleeping on the couch, a mask on, hooked up to an anti-snoring contraptio that’s pumping oxygen into his nose and mouth. She sits on a chair across from him and watches him, the MECHANICAL SOUND dominating the room. Finally, she gets up and wakes up Louie. He sits up.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: re: contraption) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: For my snoring.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: But it’s so loud!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Should I turn it off?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes!! He turns it off and removes the mask. She laughs. The roo dead quiet. They sit there, staring at each other, inches away, with decades of marriage keeping them quiet and aware. Finally, Louie reaches over and touches her face with his hand. Clears the hair from her eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: AGNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want to come up?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Please. She takes his hand and leads him up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you, Ag.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 199
dialogues.text: Agnes drives into the Metro North parking lot, tears streaming down her face. HINDI MUSIC PLAYS ON THE RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes gets out of the car, opens the back and takes out a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train speeds through Connecticut landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Train Conductor we met on Agnes’ first ride into Manhattan comes by.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Tickets please! Agnes holds out a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: One way to Grand Central.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: You know, it’s cheaper if you--

dialogues.speaker: . AGNES TRAIN PORTRAITS
dialogues.text: We move through a series of portraits showing Agnes’s reflections in the window with the lights changing as the train moves. She is absolutely fascinated by her own imag woman she is just now getting to know and like. EXT. ROBERT’S TOWNHOUSE. WEST VILLAGE - DAY 204 The cab pulls away leaving Agnes standing across the stre from Robert’s townhouse. She picks up her suitcase. Takes a deep breath. Can’t bri herself to cross over. She looks around. The sun gets in her eyes. She lets it. She tries to cross over again, but can’t quite do it. She suddenly sees Robert appear in the window. Alone, he seems even more handsome, more attractive, more vulnerable. He spots her standing there in the street and waves to he She waves back. He stares for a beat, confused. She shakes her head ever slightly. Alarmed, he picks up his phone and dials. HER PHONE RINGS She answers.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mata, please.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. They stare at each other while on the phone; he - above i the window; she - down on the street.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You can’t do this to me.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I’m not. Not to you. You’ll be fine. He quickly steps away from the window toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: No! Stay there. She sees him come back to the window, defeated. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They stare at each other for a long beat, listening to ea other BREATHING. AGNES (CONT’D) We'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnes is sitting on the grass next to her suitcase. She’s been here for awhile. From time to time she closes her eyes and looks up, letti the sun caress her face. THE PHONE RINGS IN HER PURSE. Agnes watches the daylight moon above. Smiles to herself. She’s made her peace. THE PHONE KEEPS RINGINGShe looks around and we pull back see: TOURISTS, STUDENTS, COUPLES (YOUNG and OLD), STREET

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIANS, DOG WALKERS, CHESS PLAYERS, THE HOMELESS, CHIL
dialogues.text: of all ages moving about. Agnes takes everything in. Then she fixes her gaze on a man moving through the crowd his phone to his ear. It’s Louie, clearly calling her, confused in this environment. She laughs, seeing him stop to ask a STRANGER for directi The Stranger points. Louie starts moving toward her. He finally spots her on the grass and hastens his steps. She stays still. Closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Agnes, for God's sake. Answer your phone. You said the east side of-- I've been calling-- Tears are streaming down her face, but she keeps her eyes shut. He softens.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m here. You told me to come so I’m here. What do you want me to do now?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Sit next to me. He sits besides her. She keeps her eyes closed. AGNES (CONT’D) Take my hand. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes her hand in his and holds it to his lips. Now he crying too. AGNES (CONT’D) Close your eyes. He closes his wet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIE
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Just this. For now. They sit there leaning into each other, shoulder-to-shoul holding hands with their eyes closed. The world keeps going around them without noticing. A sea humanity. The ultimate puzzle.
